I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) is rebuilding public financial management 
(PFM)  institutions  and  systems.  These  efforts  are  focused  through  the  Public  Expenditure 
Review  and  Rationalization  Programme  (PERR),  which  comprises  nine  projects,  including 
Project 6, financial management improvement programme (FMIP), and Project 9, for improving 
statutory authority governance. The PERR is a joint Government-donor program coordinated by 
the multi-agency PERR implementation committee. Key participating development partners are 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), 
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and World Bank.  
 
2.  During the 2006 Country Programming Mission, the Government requested technical 
assistance  (TA)  from  ADB  to  support  PERR-related  activities.  The  TA  was  included 
subsequently  in  the  PNG  country  strategy  and  program  2006–2010.1 TA  fact-finding  was 
conducted in March 2007 during the joint-donor PERR mission.2 The Government confirmed TA 
goals, purpose and scope, which are summarized in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The objective of PERR Project 9 is to improve the governance of statutory authorities by 
strengthening the accountability framework, with the aim of improving expenditure control and 
realizing  fiscal  savings.  The  proliferation  of  statutory  authorities  in  recent  years  has  been 
accompanied by a trend for less clear roles and responsibilities and less effective national 
government  policy  coordination  and  oversight.  There  are  now  over  200  non-commercial 
statutory  authorities  and  the  list  is  growing.  As  a  consequence,  governance  issues  have 
emerged,  and  weakened  budgetary  control  has  brought  unchecked  expenditure  growth. 
Moreover, accountability and disclosure requirements are often ignored or inadequate, and 
financial  management  information  is  either  unavailable  or  incomplete.  Limited  control  is 
exercised over the administrative and broader operating costs of these agencies, and significant 
public funds have been inappropriately retained, invested or otherwise misused. As a result, the 
Government is less able to allocate resources to priority areas of expenditure.4  
 
4.  In 2005, the PERR implementation committee requested a review of statutory authority 
governance arrangements. The review concluded that (i) the large number and small size of 
statutory  authorities  undermine  oversight  provided  by  the  Auditor-General’s  Office  and  the 
Parliamentary public accounts committee; (ii) the Public Finances (Management) Act (PFMA) 
provides for assessments of statutory authorities, but these assessments are inadequate; (iii) 
annual budgetary controls and other central controls apply in principle but not in practice; (iv) 
the  accountability  framework  varies  significantly  among  statutory  authorities;  (v)  PFMA 
regulations do not define clearly the actions to be followed in relation to accountability reports; 
and (vi) statutory authority managers are not held accountable for performance.5 In addition,

5.  In response, the review recommended that (i) the PFMA be amended to make it more 
specifically applicable to statutory authorities, leading to a more finely tuned accountability 
regime; (ii) the PFMA and budget procedures be amended so that public monies received by 
statutory authorities are paid gross to the consolidated revenue fund and that statutory authority 
expenditures  be  subject  to  annual  parliamentary  appropriation;  (iii)  an  assessment  of 
management  performance  be  undertaken  as  a  prelude  to  a  risk-based  rationalization  and 
restructuring of the statutory authority sector; and (iv) punitive action be taken under PFMA 
Section 63(8) against delinquent submitters of reports and financial statements.   
 
6.  The  objective  of  PERR  Project  6,  or  FMIP,  is  to  implement  best  practice  and 
transparency in PFM within and among national, provincial, and local governments. The FMIP 
has contributed significantly to reducing the backlog of provincial government financial reports, 
but the main FMIP focus at present, through the ADB-supported Financial Management Project 
(FMP),6 is  to  implement  an  integrated  financial  management  system  (IFMS)  in  national 
Government  agencies.  The  Government  has  decided  to  refocus  the  FMIP  on  its  broader 
objectives by developing a medium-term financial management strategy (MTFMS). Terms of 
reference for developing the MTFMS have been finalized, and an MTFMS working group is 
being  established.  The  MTFMS  working  group  will  comprise  deputy  secretary-level 
representatives from the departments of National Planning and Monitoring, Treasury, Finance, 
Education, Health, and Works; Auditor-General’s Office; Public Sector Reform Management 
Unit; and Provincial Administration of Milne Bay Province. 
 
7.  The MTFMS will provide a medium-term framework for PFM reform, which will include 
building  transparency  for  financial  transactions  and  establishing  credible  sanctions  for 
improperly using public monies. Specifically, the MTFMS scope will cover (i) budget preparation; 
(ii) budget execution; (iii) accounting for all national and subnational agencies; (iv) cash and 
bank  management;  (v)  debt  management;  (vi)  financial  and  performance  reporting  and 
monitoring, including for statutory authorities and state-owned enterprises; (vii) internal controls 
and audit; and (viii) external scrutiny that includes the Auditor-General’s Office, Parliament and 
civil society.  
 
8.  ADB has provided early assistance for MTFMS preparations through small-scale TA 
4829-PNG: Preparing Supplementary Financing for the Financial Management Project.7 This 
has supported the preparation of a background paper, which will provide important input into the 
MTFMS  development  process.8 The  Government  intends  for  the  MTFMS  to  be  developed 
through  a  participatory  process  involving  consultation  with  departmental  secretaries, 
constitutional  office  holders  (particularly  the  Auditor-General),  stakeholders  (including 
development partners), and civil society (including media and business leaders). The public 
expenditure  and  financial  accountability  (PEFA)  performance-measurement  framework  will

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will promote good governance through improved transparency, accountability 
and efficiency in managing and using public resources. Specifically, the TA will improve the 
financial oversight and governance of statutory authorities, and will support the consultative 
preparation and socialization of the MTFMS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Statutory  Authorities Component. The TA will support the preparation of a policy 
submission to the National Executive Council (NEC), sponsored by the Minister for Treasury. 
The NEC policy submission will outline proposed amendments to the PFMA and selected 
statutory authority legislation, with the objective of improving the governance framework for both 
non-commercial  and  commercial  statutory  authorities,  with  an  immediate  focus  on  non-
commercial statutory authorities.  
 
11.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  (i)  recommend  to  the  national  Government  a  whole-of-
government framework to enhance the accountability of statutory authorities that is consistent 
with good international practice and explicitly identifies strategies and incentives to encourage 
compliance and (ii) prepare, in conjunction with the preparation of the framework, and based on 
a preliminary review of the statutory authorities in Appendix 2, an implementation plan for 
Treasury  review  and  agreement.  The  implementation  plan  will  (i)  present  the  approach  to 
prioritizing  the  review  of  an  initial  group  of  statutory  authorities;  (ii)  review  and  suggest 
amendments to the PFMA to make it more specifically applicable to statutory authorities and to 
strengthen oversight arrangements; (iii) review and suggest amendments to the PFMA and 
budget procedures to improve the remittance of public monies received by statutory authorities 
to the Consolidated Revenue Fund; (iv) review and suggest amendments to the PFMA that will 
require statutory authorities to receive annual parliamentary authorization for their expenditure 
budgets;  (v)  review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  improve  performance 
assessments of statutory authorities; (vi) review and suggest amendments to the PFMA to 
improve the regime for statutory authority financial accountability and management; (vii) review 
the PFMA and individual statutory authority acts to ensure consistency on matters of financial 
management and good governance; (viii) review and propose amendments to the PFMA and 
other applicable legislation to sharpen penalties and improve processes for applying them for 
the late or inadequate provision of financial information; and (ix) assess the ability of statutory 
authorities to comply with the proposed PFMA amendments, including identifying resource 
requirements and capacity constraints. 
 
12.  The PFMA refers at present to “public bodies.” The suggested PFMA amendments will 
define more clearly statutory authorities and list those to which the amended law would apply, 
as is the approach taken by the Regulatory Statutory Authorities Act 2004, Appendix 2. The 
proposed statutory authorities to be reviewed are listed under Appendix 2 and are categorized 
with “A, B, and C” as a possible order of prioritization, subject to the implementation plan 
developed and agreed as part of this TA. The implementation plan will be prepared based on a 
preliminary review of the statutory authorities in Appendix 2.

4   
13.  MTFMS Component. In close consultation with the MTFMS working group and sponsor 
group, the TA will support the development and socialization of the MTFMS. The main output of 
the working group will be an agreed MTFMS. This will include (i) a statement of the ultimate 
objectives of the whole PFM cycle, together with a roadmap showing how these objectives can 
be achieved over the period of the strategy through appropriate phasing and sequencing of 
activities; (ii) leadership and management arrangements, including monitoring and oversight; (iii) 
reviews of the PFM responsibilities of institutions and officers at different levels of government; 
(iv)  incentives,  rewards,  and  sanctions  underpinning  these  roles  and  responsibilities;  (v) 
recommendations  for  changes  to  the  legislative  and  regulatory  frameworks;  (vi) 
recommendations for developing an information and communications technology infrastructure, 
including  ownership  and  maintenance;  (vii)  a  change-management  program  for  MTFMS 
implementation;  (viii)  consideration  of  human  resource  implications,  including  development 
requirements  and  an  analysis  of  training  needs;  (ix)  an  analysis  of  risks;  (x)  an  MTFMS 
communications and public relations program and dissemination plan; (xi) time-bound action 
plans and indicative costs of strategy implementation; and (xii) monitoring indicators. 
 
14.  The TA will support consultations with the PERR implementation committee, national 
and provincial government agencies, and other stakeholders, including civil society groups and 
development partners. The TA will also support the preparation of a PEFA PFM assessment, 
which will provide the basis for monitoring and evaluating the achievement of MTFMS objectives. 
Consultations will consider existing interventions, such as PERR and other public expenditure 
reviews  or  control  framework  reviews  conducted  jointly  with  stakeholders,  the  Fiscal 
Responsibility Act, the original FMIP overarching plan, and PFM guidance documents from 
other jurisdictions. 
 
15.  The MTFMS will identify overarching PFM objectives and provide a roadmap outlining 
the intermediate objectives on the way to achieving them. Its scope will be the PFM cycle in 
national,  provincial,  and  local  governments,  including  budget  preparation  and  execution, 
accounting, cash management, debt management, financial reporting, performance reporting 
and monitoring, internal audit, and external scrutiny by the auditor-general and parliament. The 
MTFMS  will  also  identify  the  potential  constraints,  including  institutional  impediments,  to 
achieving these improvements and suggest ways of overcoming them. It will address how the 
strategy’s scope fits with other PFM and related reforms, both ongoing and planned, and how 
PFM information can be linked with other performance information. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  TA total cost is estimated at $650,000 equivalent. ADB will provide a grant of $500,000 
from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan, to cover consulting services, 
report production, and miscellaneous administrative and workshop costs. The Government will 
provide  the  remaining  $150,000  equivalent  as  in-kind  contributions  to  cover  office 
accommodation and support services (Appendix 3). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Department of Treasury will be the Executing Agency for the statutory authorities’ 
component, and the Department of Finance will be the Executing Agency for the MTFMS 
component. The statutory authorities’ consultants will report to the secretary of the Department 
of Treasury through the deputy secretary, who serves as chair of the PERR implementation 
committee.  The  MTFMS  consultants  will  report  to  the  deputy  secretary  of  finance.  The 
Department  of  Treasury  is  establishing  a  multi-agency  team  to  work  with  the  statutory

5
authorities’ consultants, which will comprise representatives from the departments of Treasury, 
Finance, and National Planning and Monitoring, as well as from other agencies. 
 
18.  The statutory authorities component will require international consultants (6 person-
months)  and  national  consultants  (6  person-months)  with  skills  in  legal  and  institutional 
arrangements for statutory authorities. The MTFMS component will require an international 
consultant (5 person-months) and a national consultant (8 person-months) with public financial 
management skills. 
 
19.  All consultants will be selected and engaged as individuals in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Appendix 4 
presents the outline terms of reference for the consulting services. The TA is expected to be 
implemented over 12 months commencing in July 2007 and finishing in June 2008. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Papua  New  Guinea  for  Support  for  Public  Expenditure  Review  and 
Rationalization, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Statutory Authorities Component 
1.  The Technical assistance (TA) will support the preparation of a policy submission to the 
Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  National  Executive  Council  (NEC),  sponsored  by  the  Minister  for 
Treasury. The NEC policy submission will outline proposed amendments to the Public Finances 
(Management) Act (PFMA) and to statutory authority legislation, with the objective of improving the 
governance framework for statutory authorities, both commercial and not, with an immediate focus 
on non-commercial ones. The statutory authority consultants will have regular consultation with the 
relevant staff of the departments of Treasury and Finance, the Attorney-General’s Office, and other 
relevant  Government  agencies.  The  statutory  authority  consultants  will,  at  the  end  of  the 
consultancy,  provide  a  joint  report  to  the  secretary  of  the  Department  of  Treasury  and  the 
implementation committee of the Public Expenditure Review and Rationalization Program (PERR), 
outlining the work completed and related issues.  
 
1.  Legal Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
2.  The  international  legal  expert  will  have  a  professional  legal  qualification.  Exposure  to 
accountability arrangements for statutory authorities or similar bodies is essential, as are skills and 
experience in legal drafting. PNG experience is highly desirable. The legal expert will be the team 
leader for the statutory authorities component and coordinate the activities of the statutory authority 
expert and the national legal expert. 
 
3.  The expert will work in close cooperation with the statutory authority expert and the national 
legal  expert  to  suggest  legal  amendments  to  relevant  legislation  and  to  prepare  the  policy 
submission to NEC, in particular to do the following:  
(i)  Recommend  to  the  national  Government  a  whole-of-government  framework  to 
enhance  the  accountability  of  statutory  authorities  that  is  consistent  with  good 
international practice and explicitly identifies strategies and incentives to encourage 
compliance. 
(ii)  In conjunction with the preparation of the framework, and based on a preliminary 
review of the statutory authorities in Appendix 2, prepare an implementation plan for 
Treasury  review  and  agreement.  The  implementation  plan  will  lay  out  how  to 
prioritize the review of an initial group of statutory authorities. 
(iii)  Review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  make  it  more  specifically 
applicable to  statutory  authorities and  to  strengthen  oversight  arrangements.  In 
doing so, the legal expert should consider whether changes might be better effected 
through other means, such as implementing regulations, notifications, etc. 
(iv)  Review and suggest amendments to the PFMA and budget procedures to improve 
the remittance of public monies received by statutory authorities to the Consolidated 
Revenue Fund. 
(v)  Review and suggest amendments to the PFMA requiring that statutory authorities 
receive annual parliamentary authorization for their expenditure budgets. 
(vi)  Review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  improve  the  performance 
assessments of statutory authorities. 
(vii)  Review and suggest amendments to the PFMA to improve the regime for statutory 
authority financial accountability and its management. 
(viii)  Review  the  PFMA  and  relevant  individual  statutory  authority  acts  to  ensure 
consistency on matters of financial management and good governance.

12  Appendix 4 
 
(ix)  Review and propose amendments to the PFMA and other applicable legislation to 
sharpen  penalties  and  improve  processes  for  applying  them  for  the  late  or 
inadequate provision of financial information. 
 
2.  Statutory Authority Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
4.  The statutory authority expert will be experienced in reviewing the institutional governance 
arrangements of statutory authorities or similar bodies. The expert will have experience and skills 
in reviewing statutory authority management and operations from the perspective of governance 
and operational efficiency. PNG experience is highly desirable.  
 
5.  The expert will work in close cooperation with the International and national legal experts to 
suggest legal amendments to relevant legislation and to prepare the policy submission to NEC, in 
particular to do the following:  
(i)  Recommend  to  the  national  Government  a  whole-of-government  framework  to 
enhance  the  accountability  of  statutory  authorities  that  is  consistent  with  good 
international practice and explicitly identifies strategies and incentives to encourage 
compliance. 
(ii)  In conjunction with the preparation of the framework, and based on a preliminary 
review of the statutory authorities in Appendix 2, prepare an implementation plan for 
Treasury review and agreement. The implementation plan will present the approach 
to prioritizing the review of an initial group of statutory authorities. 
(iii)  Review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  make  it  more  specifically 
applicable to statutory authorities and to strengthen oversight arrangements. 
(iv)  Review and suggest amendments to the PFMA and budget procedures to improve 
the remittance of public monies received by statutory authorities to the Consolidated 
Revenue Fund. 
(v)  Review and suggest amendments to the PFMA requiring that statutory authorities 
receive annual parliamentary authorization for their expenditure budgets. 
(vi)  Review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  improve  performance 
assessments of statutory authorities. 
(vii)  Review  and  suggest  amendments  to  the  PFMA  to  improve  statutory  authority 
financial accountability and its management regime. 
(viii)  Review the PFMA and individual statutory authority acts to ensure consistency on 
matters of financial management and good governance. 
(ix)  Review and propose amendments to the PFMA and other applicable legislation to 
sharpen penalties and improve processes for applying those penalties for the late or 
inadequate provision of financial information. 
(x)  Assess capacity constraints and identify resource requirements to comply with the 
proposed PFMA amendments. 
 
3.  Legal Expert (national, 6 person-months) 
6.  The  national  legal  expert  will  have  a  legal  qualification.  Exposure  to  accountability 
arrangements  for  statutory  authorities  or  similar  bodies  is  highly  desirable,  as  are  skills  and 
experience in legal drafting. The expert will work in close cooperation with the statutory authority 
expert and the international legal expert to suggest legal amendments to relevant legislation and to 
prepare the policy submission to NEC.

14  Appendix 4 
 
(viii)  arrange four national workshops, four provincial workshops, and the PEFA PFM 
assessment workshop. 
 
2.  Public Financial Management Expert (national, 8 person-months) 
10.  The national PFM expert will work under the guidance and coordination of the international 
PFM expert to help the MTFMS working group to develop and socialize the MTFMS. In addition to 
appropriate academic and/or professional qualifications, the expert will have at least 3 years of 
PFM experience. Highly developed written and communication skills are essential.
